article.headline: Providence 63, Seton Hall 60
article.story: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. (AP) -- After losing two straight at the buzzer, Providence survived the final horn this time, with a lot of angst. Ryan Gomes and Marcus Douthit each scored 14 points and Providence had to sweat out three game-tying 3-point attempts by Seton Hall in the final eight seconds in posting a 63-60 victory Monday night. "It felt like a half an hour," Douthit said of the interminable final seconds that got Providence (9-3, 1-1 Big East) back on the winning track and ended the Pirates (11-3, 1-1) eight-game winning streak. "I was just hoping the ball did not go down," Douthit said. "Two days I was hoping the same thing so this time I was praying it wouldn't go in." The Friars' last three games have had incredible endings. Texas beat the then-No. 25 Friars 79-77 last Monday in overtime in a game that the officials needed 7 minutes of videotape review to decide whether the final shot counted. Rutgers added to the Friars woes on Saturday, taking advantage of a couple of missed free throws and hitting two late 3-pointers, including a game winner with less than a second to play, in a 65-64 win. "We missed free throws again tonight, and then the open looks, I was like `Oh, my goodness, I'm not that bad of a person to have it happen three times in one week," Providence coach Tim Welsh said. Andre Barrett, Andre Sweet and John Allen all had shots bounce off the rim in the final seconds as Seton Hall's 13-game winning streak at the Continental Airlines Arena ended. "We weren't thinking about what happened to them in the past," said Barrett, who led the Pirates with 14 points. "We were trying to win the game. It came down to three shots at the end of the game. We had decent looks. They just went in and out." Sweet added 12 points for Seton Hall and Allen and J.R. Morris each had 11 in the game in which neither team led by more than six points in the second half. Douthit gave the Friars the lead for good at 59-57, taking a pass from Gomes and hitting a foul-line jumper with 1:54 to play. Tuuka Kotti stole a pass from Barrett on the ensuing possession and Gomes stretched the lead to 61-57 by putting in the rebound of Kotti's fastbreak miss. A layup by Donnie McGrath gave the Friars a 63-57 lead with a minute to play, but Barrett closed the gap to 63-60 with a 3-pointer with 49 seconds to go. Kotti and Sheiku Kabba, who had 12 points, both missed the front ends of 1-and-ls with 30 and 13 seconds to play, respectively, to give the Pirates a final chance. Morris missed a game-tying 3-pointer after Kotti's miss and then Seton Hall had a trio of chances to tie in the closing seconds, with each shot bouncing off the rim. Barrett missed with 8 seconds to go. Sweet missed with 4 seconds left while Allen got his off with less than a second to go. "I thought it had a chance," Allen said. "The one Dre (Barrett) took, I thought that was good." Sweet had capped a 7-0 run with a baseline layup to give Seton Hall a 55-51 lead with 5:02 to play. McGrath, who missed two late free throws that proved costly in the loss at Rutgers, got the Friars within a point with a 3-pointer with 3:59 to go and Kabba hit another 3 to give Providence a 57-54 lead. Allen tied the game at 57 with 2:20 to go. Providence, which trailed by 10 points with 8:26 left in the opening half, used a 23-9 spurt to take a 34-30 halftime lead. The Friars, who had gotten most of their points inside, got three consecutive 3-pointers from Kabba and McGrath late in the run.
